body:
Hey @gianm @b-slim 

Please find the changes as @gianm wanted in his previous comment. Have moved the responsibility to print merge pool to the pool emitter. Have also renamed ExecutorServiceMonitor to ProcessingMonitor so that we can use the same monitor to print all processing related data. 

Let me know if it looks okay. Sorry for delaying this. Will be regular from now.

My previous measurements of accuracy only considered single sketches.
I run some experiments merging sketches and added the results to the page linked above.
Simply speaking, Druid HyperLogLogCollector doesn't seem to be a correct implementation of the HLL algorithm. The error of merging is way beyond theoretical guarantees.

Hey @fanwu72 

I can't speak for the original authors but the expressions and virtual columns are used in the queries generated by SQL so it seems fair to follow the same guidelines that they're an experimental feature subject to change.

There's an open issue to document them here: https://github.com/druid-io/druid/issues/3634
@Dylan1312 Thanks for the explanation.

@gianm my apologies for not being able to get back to this for so long, but finally :)

and also thanks to @a2l007 for reminders to get this done .

Does this PR looks okay? Can I start working on the other one?

you have only one historical?

```BETWEEN CURRENT_TIMESTAMP AND CURRENT_TIMESTAMP - INTERVAL '20' HOUR```

should be

```BETWEEN CURRENT_TIMESTAMP - INTERVAL '20' HOUR AND CURRENT_TIMESTAMP```

(the order matters)

In the first case, the query is correctly simplified to a nil resultset.

Hi @michas2,

What you are asking is not possible with any version of Druid. But some related things are possible.

Essentially the `druid.coordinator.merge.on` and related "merge" and "append" tasks were created to do merging of segments "horizontally" across the timeline. The idea being that if you have a bunch of single, small hourly segments then they may merge them into larger 4-hourly, 5-hourly, whatever segments. They are limited in that they only work on unsharded segments.

Kafka ingestion (as you may be aware) often creates more than one segment per interval. And also, because it can accept late data, it doesn't make so much sense to do merges "horizontally".

The ongoing work being referred to in the docs is compaction (http://druid.io/docs/latest/ingestion/tasks.html#compaction-task) and auto compaction (#5102). That work can also merge sharded segments "vertically" -- meaning it can do things like merge a dozen small hourly segments _for the same hour_ into a smaller number of hourly segments _for the same hour_. There is enough there in master to try out auto-compaction. And even older versions (ones that have actually been released) have the ability to do manual compaction through the compaction task, or even through Hadoop jobs using the `dataSource` inputSpec.

Future work is intended to include "super compaction", i.e. automatically scaling it out, possibly with an option to do it with or without Hadoop.

The end goal is that you just flip a switch and it happens in the background, regardless of the method of ingestion you originally chose (kafka, batch, something custom, etc).

The logs are saying that the Coordinator is failing because it's configured to create two replicas of each segment within that datasource. You can either spin up two historical instances or configure that datasource in the Coordinator UI by editing the rules so that it only loads one replica.
@Dylan1312  thanks , I got it . You're a genius !

Or, it might be much better to handle nullability centralized, not to require for each implementer of `AggregatorFactory` to remember about nullability. E. g. wrap with `Comparator.nullsFirst(aggFactory.getComparator())` at the usage sites of `getComparator()`. Or add a final method `getNullableComparator()` to `AggregatorFactory` and declare `protected abstract getComparator()`.

Hey @gianm - would you be able to have a look over this please :)? Noticed you created this class so hopefully you can comment if it makes sense or not.

What do you get if you do the Druid SQL query:

```select * from raw_events where __time >= timestamp '2017-05-30 00:00:00' and __time < timestamp '2017-06-02 00:00:00'```

Do you see two different rows that should have rolled up together?

It's possible that you are missing the time factor (maybe you need to add a time component to your groupby query on raw_data that you're using to verify).

Would it work to use authentication chains for this? Something like:

```
druid.auth.authenticationChain=["basic", "allowAll"]
```

I'm not sure authentication chains would be suitable for this. For example, if an unauthenticated user sends a request then the basic authenticator will fail and then the user will be given full access via the allowAll authenticator. With this change, we would define a permission such that a request from an unauthenticated user will succeed or fail based on the permission.

Ah, I see. Thanks for explaining. It sounds like you want an 'anonymous' user that would potentially have some permissions attached to it. IMO, the best way to do that would be to create a new AnonymousAuthenticator that is like AllowAll (in that it always accepts the user) but is also _not_ like AllowAll (in that it can point to a custom authorizer, not hardcoded to use the AllowAllAuthorizer).

So in the end your config would look like this.

```
druid.auth.authenticationChain=["basic", "anonymous"]

druid.auth.authenticator.anonymous.type=anonymous
druid.auth.authenticator.anonymous.identity=defaultUser
druid.auth.authenticator.anonymous.authorizerName=myBasicAuthorizer

# ... usual configs for basic authentication go here ...
```

And you'd have "defaultUser" as the identity for anonymous users.

I am thinking one benefit of this approach is that it works not just with "basic" authentication, but also with kerberos, etc. You could use it to chain an anonymous mode after any kind of authentication.

Does that sound like it will work?
Btw, could you please fill out the project CLA at: http://druid.io/community/cla.html so we can accept your contributions?
Thanks for the contribution. Could you please fill out the project CLA at http://druid.io/community/cla.html so we can accept it?

Thanks for your feedback. I think having an anonymous authenticator sounds like a good idea. This would involve creating a new extension, correct? I'm unfamiliar with kerberos but the thought of this change working with other extensions came across my mind. I'll take a look into making an anonymous authenticator.

RE the CLA, do I need to sign it for every contribution? I had signed it recently for another pull request so let me know if that didn't work. Thanks.

@jon-wei @clintropolis I removed the term "SinglePhase" from all related classes. Instead, `ParallelIndexSupervisorTask` has a `ParallelIndexTaskRunner` which actually runs the task. Currently there is a single implementation, i.e., `SinglePhaseParallelIndexTaskRunner`, for `ParallelIndexTaskRunner` to support indexing without shuffle. We can add `TwoPhaseParallelIndexTaskRunner` for indexing with shuffle later.
@jihoonson thanks for the review!
Duplicate of #4349

Hmm, I've been thinking about this and would like to revert all changes in this PR and reduce this PR's scope to disable audit logging by default. The reasons are

- Moving audit logs to deep storage requires quite a lot of changes and introduces new design issues like audit log formats (single JSON per file, all JSONs in a single file, etc), log file name convention, how to efficiently search inserted/deleted segments from logs, how to manage increasing logs (like automatic cleanup) and so on. I don't want to make an effort for this kind of issue that there may not be a good use case.
- If there is any use case for `http://<OVERLORD_IP>:<port>/druid/indexer/v1/task/{taskId}/segments`, moving audit logs to deep storage will cause performance regression issue. 
  - At first, I tried to address this issue by using a combination of inserted/deleted segment IDs as the file name, but it's not feasible because 1) there can be a lot of inserted/deleted segments and 2) some task actions requiring auditing (like `ResetDataSourceMetadataAction`) doesn't have segment information.
- If there is any user application based on `taskLog` table, there is still a workaround of increasing max size of a blob.

@gianm @jon-wei what do you think?
Just check out，we still use foreach topN ，any help would be greate

In the end, I stil use a historical node, and I use kafka index service to replace tranquilty. But I set "taskDuration" long enough,so It wont genereate segment so off,Then I can set segment genereate timeout short to make it fail.
Thats resolved

Note to future devs: Please always remember to include benchmarks for performance improvements :)

It was mentioned in the dev sync that a query validation process might be helpful here.

There are two options:

1. Query validation all the time on the query deserialization. Such a feature would have to be careful not to fully materialize streaming JSON stuff when it doesn't actually want to. For example, results coming back should still retain their streaming properties, but queries might be OK to fully materialize and validate.
2. Query validation as a specific endpoint. In such a feature, there could be an endpoint where a query is posted to that simply does validation on the query but does not run it. This could help developers or administrators debug why a specific query is failing to deserialize correctly.
@clintropolis added checking the retry directly, as well as added some more tests to `io.druid.storage.google.GoogleDataSegmentKillerTest` which were stressing error modes already.

@jihoonson ok, its good now
https://youtrack.jetbrains.com/issue/IDEA-193368

I had hit it recently . I think the problem is not in the Intellij but the maven-compiler-plugin version getting used which is determined from https://search.maven.org/remotecontent?filepath=io/druid/oss-parent/2/oss-parent-2.pom to be 3.2 while configuration "annotationProcessorPaths" was introduced in version 3.5 ( see https://maven.apache.org/plugins/maven-compiler-plugin/compile-mojo.html ) which is why it is not recognized. For example manually overriding the version to 3.7 in druid-processing pom solves the problem.
we need to update the version of maven-compiler-plugin to at least 3.5 .
Hey guys, wanted to mention that I am also having this problem ever since I upgraded to 0.12.0.  This didn't seem to be a problem in 0.11.0.
Why would not we update the version of maven-compiler-plugin project-wide?
